TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs been drawn to an article in today's Australian which states that according to land rights author, Mr Peter English, the handover of the Ayers Rock title was going to the `wrong tribe'? Will the Minister inform the Senate as to the accuracy of the article and Mr English's claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to that article and I have some information in relation to it. I think the first point that should be made clear to honourable senators is that the book referred to in the article in the Australian by Mr English-I am advised that this is not his real name but a pseudonym-Land Rights, Birth Rights-The Great Australian Hoax, is published by Veritas publishing company, the same company that publishes the notorious Red over Black by Geoff McDonald which is a publication widely and enthusiastically distributed by the racist organisation known as the League of Rights.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the accuracy of the claims made by the so-called Mr English, honourable senators should know that the Mutitjulu Community Incorporated, which has been said erroneously by the Opposition and in some media coverage, such as the article in today's Australian, to be the recipient of the grant of the title will not receive title to the park. Only land trusts can hold title to land and the Mutitjulu Community Incorporated is not a land trust.

For those who remain ignorant-some appear to do so deliberately-there is a waterhole on the south side of Uluru which is named Mutitjulu. When it was necessary to form an incorporated body to receive financial assistance for the community at Uluru, the word `Mutitjulu' was chosen for the name of that body.

Under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act a land trust has been established to hold title to the park. The name of that land trust is the Uluru-Katatjuta Aboriginal Land Trust. Its function as a land trust is to hold title to the land for the benefit of all Aboriginals entitled by Aboriginal tradition to the use or occupation of the land concerned. That means that the benefits of the title extend to a wider class of Aboriginal people than those said to be the traditional owners. The benefits extend to all Aboriginal people who have traditional rights in respect of that land.

The question of traditional ownership in respect of Uluru National Park was addressed by the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, in his report on Uluru (Ayers Rock) National Park and Lake Amadeus-Luritja land claim. While Mr Justice Toohey found the park to be unavailable for claim under the provisions of the Act he noted that two of the estates comprised in the remaining land available for claim had their hearts in the park. These two estates were Uluru and Katatjuta and Mr Justice Toohey listed no fewer than 104 and 57 traditional owners respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs read statements reported in the South Australian Sunday Mail and other media as having been made by one Ali Kazak who describes himself as the Palestine Liberation Organisation's spokesman in Australia? Is he aware that Mr Ali Kazak reportedly warned that Australians could be targets for Arab extremists and cited the fact that two Austrians were earmarked for execution by the hijackers of the Achille Lauro in the belief that they were Australians? Under what arrangements is this gentleman permitted to live in Australia? Is he a permanent resident? Is he being offered or afforded de facto diplomatic status? Further, has the Government made any inquiries with respect to this gentleman and his alleged threats? If not, will the Government take action to make inquiries and deal with him if he is not a permanent resident of Australia?

—The situation is that Mr Kazak is not recognised by the Government as a Palestine Liberation Organisation representative and his views are simply those of an Australian citizen. The Australian Government has received no suggestion from official PLO sources that the views expressed by Mr Kazak in the newspaper article reflect official PLO thinking. To the extent that the reported statements of Mr Kazak do give rise to some concern, as they have in some quarters, I simply make the point that has been made publicly since by Mr Young, the Special Minister of State, who is responsible for the Australian Federal Police and for Government activities in this area generally-that Australia has an effective national counter terrorist capability, developed through co-operation between Federal and State governments, and a national anti terrorist plan has been prepared to ensure a co-ordinated response to an incident and provide for effective crisis management should that circumstance ever arise. Equally, we have a very well developed intelligence exchange system with many other countries on the subject of terrorism and, of course, we have domestic arrangements in place which keep the Government very well informed of what might be likely to occur in this area. So I believe I can say with some conviction on behalf of the Government that there is no ground for particular concern arising out of the reported statements to which the honourable senator has referred.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACCORD BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT AND THE AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, relates to the accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to recent criticisms of the accord? Is the Minister satisfied that, with the implementation of provisions of the accord, under this Government Australia's employment picture is improving and will continue to improve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice in last Saturday's Australian that the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Shack, had a polemic about the accord and what he claimed were the assorted defects of the accord or, rather, the results which the accord delivered. After reading that polemic I can understand why the new Leader of the Opposition made him the shadow Minister for Education and, certainly, why he moved him from employment and industrial relations. Indeed, this is probably one of the few bull's eyes that the present Opposition leader has scored.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts, of course, are that notwithstanding Mr Shack's description of the accord as lead weight dragging down Australia's already battered international competitiveness, real unit labour costs are lower now than they have been at any time since the 1960s and are lower than they were for many times even in the 1960s. Seven years of the Fraser-Howard coalition failed either to restore business profitability to its present levels or to bring real unit labour costs down to their present levels even though at the same time that combination almost trebled the level of unemployment. One would have thought that any combination which trebled the level of unemployment would at least have been able to bring real unit labour costs and the inflation rate down. But the Fraser-Howard team at no stage managed to do that.

The sort of polemic published in last weekend's Australian, I suppose, is even more alarming in that not even Malcolm Fraser would have sanctioned that sort of inadequate and inaccurate analysis which disregarded the facts and relied entirely on ideological dogma for its backbone. The fact is that because of the success of the accord almost half a million additional jobs have been generated, the inflation rate has been cut almost in half, and real unit labour costs are at their lowest level since the 1960s. We have already achieved two years of real gross domestic product growth approaching 5 per cent and we are on course for a third year of real GDP growth approaching 5 per cent. In addition the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions last month agreed to discount by up to 2 per cent the national wage in the first half of 1986 and to observe the accord for a further two years. So barring some catastrophic unforeseeable event beyond the control of any Australian government, because of the cementing of the accord for at least another two years Australia can anticipate a continuation of the extremely high growth rates which we have seen in the last few years, a reduction in the deficit, a reduction in unemployment, and the restoration of our international competitiveness-partly brought about because of the devaluation of the dollar-the adverse potential effects of which have been taken care of by the agreement to discount the national wage in the first half of 1986. In contrast to that I note with genuine regret that the best that the Leader of the Opposition can offer or look forward to as his alternative wages and basic economic policy is five years of industrial warfare.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the Acting Prime Minister's statement of several days ago supporting the action of the United States of America in intercepting and forcing to land an Egyptian aircraft containing hijackers. I refer also to the message conveyed to the USA by the Acting Prime Minister as read out to the Senate by the Minister. Do we understand the Minister to say that this message, as read out, is to be understood to convey full support for the US action in intercepting the aircraft and subsequent events?

—The message that I read out expresses clearly the Government's understanding for the efforts taken by the United States Administration to bring the perpetrators to justice. As such I repeat that it is quite consistent not with the response given some days ago but in fact with the response given yesterday in the House of Representatives by Mr Bowen to a question put to him by Mr Howard.

—Has the Minister for Education seen the article in the Sydney Mail of 13 October in which the President of the Queensland Teachers Union stated that he feared for the safety of students in the Torres Strait because of the poor state of their school buildings? Does the Minister agree that there is an urgent need to upgrade those facilities? What action has been or will be taken by the Commonwealth Government to assist with the improvement of facilities on these islands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article containing the Queensland Teachers Union's comment on the schools in the Torres Strait Islands. I suppose more to the point, in terms of Senator Crowley's interest in this matter, I have seen those schools on the islands. I recently made a fairly extensive trip around the islands in the Torres Strait to inspect school facilities, and like the representatives of the Queensland Teachers Union I was very shocked and dismayed by what I saw. I suppose I have seen more disadvantaged schools in Australia than any other member of this place, by virtue of my portfolio responsibilities and the Government's very deep concern to improve facilities for the disadvantaged in education, but I have not seen facilities anywhere in Australia anything like as inadequate as those currently available to children living on islands in the Torres Strait. Nor have I seen anywhere in an Australian school teachers as ill-equipped to deal with the circumstances they are facing.
—You mean materially ill-equipped.

—I mean materially, but also they are ill-equipped in terms of inadequacy of teacher training. Most of the schools are staffed by untrained Islanders, some of whom are managing to cope quite well in these extraordinarily difficult circumstances. Nonetheless, they have not had the opportunity for teacher training that teachers in Australian schools generally have and, therefore, they have great difficulty in providing education for the children. It is also the case that until now no serious attempt has been made to develop curriculum materials which are in any way relevant to the circumstances of those children. Most of them either speak an Island language as their first language or speak some mixture of Island languages. In any case, they have had very little opportunity to hear English spoken clearly and properly until they go to school, where they may or may not have the advantage of an English-speaking teacher to teach them. The situation is one of gross disadvantage. Although members of the Queensland Government collectively must be held responsible because they have allowed this appalling situation to continue for many years, I must commend that Government on its recent decision to transfer the administration of those schools from the notorious Department of Aboriginal and Island Affairs to the Queensland Education Department. Now that that transfer is in place, I believe that the Queensland Government will be able to address more effectively the needs of these very disadvantaged children.

ANSWER.PARA: But, in the meantime, I am pleased to report to Senator Crowley and the Senate that our Government has undertaken a process of upgrading the physical facilities in those schools by making available a series of capital grants for the replacement of these appalling facilities by adequate facilities. We have already decided to fund the replacement of Mabuiag School at a cost of $670,000, St Pauls School-called Kubin in the Torres Strait-at a cost of $770,000 and a school on Coconut Island at $670,000. In addition, we have made a grant of $312,000 for Bamaga State School, $200,000 for the Thursday Island High School and $194,000 for the Thursday Island Primary School.

Clearly, the Commonwealth is playing its part in trying to provide better educational opportunities for the Torres Strait Islands schools. I hope that the Queensland Education Department will now play its part in ensuring that teacher training, proper curriculum materials and access to training for the untrained Islander teachers who wish to train and return to their island, will be made available by a co-operative effort of both governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of instances of employees on short term community employment programs, on perhaps a building project of 13 to 26 weeks, being pressured to join a union? Is he aware that said employees, if agreeing to membership of a builders union, were automatically expected to contribute to the union's superannuation scheme at a cost of $11 per week? If so, where will this $11 per week contribution by an employee of 13 weeks duration ultimately be placed? Will the Minister explain to the Senate how short term employees could benefit from compulsory superannuation contributions if the intention of the superannuation scheme is to benefit employees where the continuance of employment and contributions to such funds is assured?

—I do not know a great deal about this matter. I will have to seek a response from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations for the main part of Senator Watson's question, but I should correct one aspect of it. For the building industry in general, regardless of whether employees are community employment program short term employees, virtually all employment can be regarded as short term, just because of the nature of the building industry. Therefore, there is nothing necessarily incongruous about employees of three months duration contributing to a superannuation fund. If they returned to employment in the building industry at any time they would, I expect, continue to contribute to that fund, just as building employees in general are expected to do and are in fact doing.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: First Report for the Sixty-second Session

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the First Report for the sixty-second session of the Standing Orders Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.
That consideration of the report in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with section 121 (3) of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959, I present the annual reports and financial statements of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report thereon, for the year ended 30 June 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a paper entitled `Commonwealth Schools Commission Report for 1986' and seek leave to make a statement relating to the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the text of the statement incorporated in Hansard.
—You should read it.

—Mr Deputy President, I have had a request to read the statement. I was simply trying to facilitate the business of the Senate. I am happy to comply with that request. I present for the information of honourable senators the Commonwealth Schools Commission's report for 1986. The report makes recommendations on the detailed distribution of capital and specific purpose program funds for the 1986 calendar year, as well as a number of recommendations on the operation of the general recurrent and capital grants programs. Decisions on funding levels for general recurrent grants for the period 1985-1988 were taken last year and incorporated in States grants legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has proposed significant changes to the administration of the capital grants program. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations on the objectives for the program, including giving emphasis to upgrading and refurbishment of facilities in existing schools, particularly those serving students characterised by low socio-economic circumstances, the construction of new facilities in accordance with overall educational planning, the provision of facilities to assist schools to encourage and cater for increased student participation at years 11 and 12 and the provision of facilities to encourage equal participation by girls and boys in all areas of the curriculum and to assist in widening career options for girls.

The Government has also accepted the Commission's advice that there are significant advantages in the adoption of a more flexible approach to the allocation of Commonwealth capital funds. In 1986 there will be only a single general capital element in place of the five elements operating in 1985. There will also be two national elements: The continuation of the existing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander element and a new element for the provision of facilities for children with intellectual and/or physical disabilities, following from the transfer from the Department of Community Services of the administration of capital grants to non-government institutions providing for disabled children. To protect the Commonwealth's objectives for the capital grants program the Government has accepted the Commission's recommended criteria for eligibility and priority for Commonwealth capital funding, including giving priority to those schools serving students from communities characterised by socio-economic disadvantage.

While recognising that school authorities must continue to provide for new places, the Commission has proposed that a higher proportion of Commonwealth capital funds should be directed to the refurbishing and upgrading of existing schools. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations that by 1988 the minimum level of expenditure on refurbishing and upgrading existing schools should be 50 per cent of Commonwealth grants, subject to forward commitment obligations already entered into. Consistent with the decision to give greater emphasis in Commonwealth funding to the needs of existing schools and students, the Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that allocations to the States and Territories should be on a per capita basis. This arrangement will be phased in over three years, 1986-88, except in the Australian Capital Territory, where it is able to be implemented fully in 1986.

The Government has also accepted in principle the Commission's proposal for block capital grants to approved schools systems from 1987, dependent on the development of arrangements satisfactory to the Commonwealth in terms of the Commonwealth's policy objectives. The Department of Education will conduct further consultations with state and non-government school authorities on this matter. Similarly, the Department will advise on the details of appropriate arrangements for the allocation of grants under the two national elements of the capital grants program-the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander element and the special schools element. The Government has accepted all of the Commission's recommendations on the allocation of grants between States and Territories for the specific purpose programs. The approval of projects of national significance will be undertaken separately by the Minister in the normal way.

The Commission has also made a number of recommendations relating to the operation of the general recurrent grants program. The Government will be considering these proposals in the near future. In the meantime, the decisions announced today will enable the necessary legislation for appropriation of grants for 1986 to be finalised. I move:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason the Opposition sought to have the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) read the statement is that it is her statement; it originates in this chamber. We thought it appropriate that it should be read. It is a very important statement. Such a statement appears each year and lays down the Government's priorities and decisions in relation to the funding of schools. This statement then lays down the response of the Commonwealth Schools Commission to those guidelines. It is a statement that is looked for each year by members of the educational community, as it identifies for them exactly what are the rules under which they will operate.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be clear to anyone who listened to what the Minister presented to the Senate that this is a very different educational program from those which have operated over several years. We have seen the end this year of what might have been called the Whitlam dream of large educational funding from the Commonwealth. We have seen a rolling back of much of the funding and of much of the thrust of funding by the Commonwealth. Indeed, this report which we are considering today from the Schools Commission sets down in detail a number of areas in which funding which was sought for the schools of Australia and for the pupils of Australia has not been satisfied and for which funds have not been provided. I will mention some of those in a moment.

In addition, this statement makes clear once again the Government's intention to provide funding for fewer new places in the non-government sector and to concentrate capital funding, not on new places, but on already established places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty per cent.

—The Minister says 50 per cent. That is a changed proportion. We are seeing put into effect now the impediments to the establishment of new non-government school places which we have seen coming for a year or more. I will return to that, because the provision of fewer new places, both by the way of recurrent funding and capital funding, is a matter of great significance to the non-government sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the statement itself. The Commission in this report has identified a number of areas in which the Government's decisions on school expenditure involve rejection of the expert advice of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I have great regard for the Commonwealth Schools Commission, and when I was Minister, working in daily and constant contact with the Commonwealth Schools Commission, I formed a great regard and respect for the work of the officers. I must say that that respect has risen in the past year as I have watched officers operating under immense work pressures to meet impossible deadlines and to try to put in place very complicated new arrangements in the minimum amount of time. I think some of the officers, particularly those working in the area of recurrent expenditure, have undertaken superhuman work in a very brief time. I draw attention to the branch which was operating under Dr McMorrow, which included people such as Prue Carmel and people who contributed to this country by the dedication which they displayed to the administration of really very difficult programs being changed by a government intent upon rolling back the access of the non-government sector to funding.

In this report the commissioners have drawn attention to some of the problems. They have drawn attention to some of the advice which the Government has seen fit to reject. This included a decision by the Government to bring about a real reduction in overall schools expenditure of 1.3 per cent over their recommendations, a real reduction in program expenditure for government schools of 2.7 per cent over their recommendations, a real reduction of joint government and non-government schools programs of 3 per cent over their recommendations and a 50 per cent reduction in the participation and equity program which was announced in the May mini-Budget and which is a decision directed primarily at the most disadvantaged students within our schooling system, the ones who might think they could look most readily to a Labor Government for assistance.

We have seen a 50 per cent cutback in participation and equity program funding, much of that program funding, of course, going into schools when it was operating. We can only anticipate from the way in which the Minister has presented those cuts that the participation and equity program will end at the end of 1987 because she said that the funds would be cut in half and extended over two years. That program was a continuing program of some nine years duration, starting off under Senator Sir John Carrick as the school to work transition program, and being expanded and developed for the benefit of the most disadvantaged. The Commonwealth Schools Commission has now found it proper to draw attention to this savage cutback of 50 per cent in the participation and equity program. That must stand as one of the starkest indicators of where the priority of the Hawke Government lies. The priorities do not lie with the disadvantaged or with those in need. The people who have been undertaking, firstly, school to work transition education and, latterly, participation and equity training-that is the same kind of program but under a different name-are distraught and distressed, not on their own behalf but on behalf of the clientele for whom they have been working successfully and continually and for whom the money has now been cut off.

The Schools Commission went on to comment on the $20m reduction in the capital grants program for government and non-government schools over the careful recommendations of the Commission, the rejection of the Commission's recommendation that an additional $41.5m be allocated for what it described as urgent needs in the areas of Aboriginal education, the new arrivals element of the English as a second language program, the disadvantaged schools program and the special education program. These are all particularly distressing because they again relate to areas affecting disadvantage of one kind or another. It is in these areas that the Government has failed to respond to the Schools Commission recommendations. It is a Schools Commission which was appointed, as to the largest part of it, and selected by this Minister and by this Government and put there because it enjoyed their confidence. So much did the Commission enjoy their confidence, of course, that its operating functions have now been taken from it and taken to the Department of Education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—They certainly have been taken to the Department of Education. That is a matter of fact. It has been left with its advisory function but without its capacity to gather data and to be, as it has been over 10 years, a potent force for educational advice and change, respected on all sides. It has lost that because of the fact that it has been gutted in the way it has. In the report which the Senate is considering now the Schools Commission comments:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many of the urgent needs of students who most require special assistance to overcome aspects of educational disadvantage continue to be neglected, and in some cases exacerbated.

That is a damning statement by the Government's own Schools Commission of the Government's decisions in relation to educational funding, not just as to quantum but in terms of the priorities which the Government has set. The Government has determined that money will not go to the people described by the Schools Commission as those suffering educational disadvantage. The Commission has had occasion to say that not only will those needs continue to be neglected but also, in some cases, they will be exacerbated. I would have thought that the Minister, in bringing down her statement and identifying, as she did, the new areas of priority, might have drawn attention to those really quite trenchant criticisms by the Schools Commission and that she might have chosen to answer them, explain them or modify them by some interpretation; but to ignore them is, I think, the least responsible course that could have been taken. It is likely that Senator Ryan will face a barrage of criticism from within the educational community over the priorities laid down in these cuts. They are, in fact, Labor priorities coming from a Labor Government and it must stand or fall by them.

One of the elements of the guidelines which are the subject of this Schools Commission report relates to the capital and recurrent funding of non-government education. It is not possible to let the occasion pass without commenting on matters which arise from the report and from the guidelines on which it is based. It is quite clear now from announcements in the last week that the Government is intent on pressing ahead with a limitation in the development and growth of schools in the non-government sector; and that is, of course, in the provision of places for children to have their education in the non-government sector if that is their wish and their parents' wish. About a week ago-I do not have the date-we had from the Minister a list of some 68 new non-government schools which have been approved for recurrent funding for 1986. Those schools are grateful that they have got on the list. We have some interest in how some of them got on the list, but we will take that up at another time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the State committees.

—We hope that the committees were not influenced in any way; we will take that up at another time. What is of interest in that list is the schools that did not get listed. They have now been told that there is no funding available for the support of the parents or of the children who will attend those schools in 1986. In my State of New South Wales, 14 schools did not attract funding under the guidelines which the Government has brought down. All of those schools were established within the guidelines laid down by the Government. They have passed through the various State approval procedures and have been considered within the Commonwealth Schools Commission. We find, when it comes to the Government making a decision, that it has made a budgetary decision which has denied funding for at least 14 schools in New South Wales-or has not let them into the funding. Probably more than 20 schools across Australia will be affected. This has caused great distress among the communities, the dedicated parents, the church groups and those who have supported the schools. They are asking the simple questions: `What have we done wrong? Why have we missed out on funding?'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth while examining some of the schools so affected. I have had association with some of them. I attended a public meeting in Willoughby perhaps 18 months ago. It was held by the Armenian community to try to launch its new Armenian school. It was to be called the Hamazkaine Armenian School. I take it that the name is after an Armenian hero. This school was to be situated on land in Terrey Hills which the Armenian community has purchased. What was noteworthy about that meeting of the Armenian community was that that night, from an audience of about 400, the Armenian people either received or were pledged well over $70,000 towards the education of their children and towards what one of their spokesmen called in the newspapers this week their attempt to make a contribution to Australia.

There is absolutely no doubt that if this school were established and were to receive the recurrent funding that so many other schools receive, it would be saving money for the public education system; it would be saving New South Wales money for every child who attended it. It would provide another community focus for one of the finest communities in Sydney, the Armenian community. These people cannot understand what they have done wrong and what they are to do next. Did the fact that they are Armenian cause them to be refused funding? Is that why they were not given money?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be absurd.

—They do not know why it was. Is it because they come from Liberal electorates generally? Is that why they are refused funding? Is it because they are a strong, coherent cultural group? Is it because they would include in their offerings the teaching of the Armenian language? When we were in government, when I was Minister for Education and also when my colleague Sir John Carrick was the Minister for Education, our policy was clear. Any group that established a school and complied with the conditions of State registration so that it was adequate in educational terms-the school had to meet a couple of simple conditions, such as being a non-profit organisation and a few other conditions which the Commonwealth applied-would then qualify automatically for this kind of recurrent funding.
—And rightly so.

—And rightly so, as my colleague says. I want the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, to appear before the Armenian community in Sydney, and tell Dr Paul Sarian and his school committee what sin they have committed that they cannot get recurrent funding. If the Minister does not wish to tell us about the Armenian school, let us ask her about another school, a primary school at Harris Park operated by the Maronite Sisters of the Holy Family. I know this school because I opened the primary school and I know the sisters.
—It is an underprivileged area.

—It is an underprivileged area. It is in the Federal seat of Parramatta. The sisters contacted me this week in great distress, having been unable to have their phone calls returned by their local member, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). They cannot get any response from Mr Brown, so they are coming to the Liberal Party senators to try to find out what sin they have committed. All they wish to do is to carry on the education of the children who have gone through their primary school at Our Lady of Lebanon School, at Alice Street, Harris Park.
—The Government has found the money for a football stadium.

—The Government has found the money for a football stadium and lots of circuses, but when it comes to supporting a Maronite Christian community in Harris Park with recurrent funding for the education of children in a school that is already there at primary level, no money is available. That community does not understand the criteria which have been applied and which somehow it has failed to meet. It cannot find out why it was low on the priority list. It has already spent over $300,000 in setting up the school, anticipating that it was contributing to this country and that it would be able to get recurrent support for its children. Every non-government secondary school I have been to in the western suburbs of Sydney has every available place full and every principal has long waiting lists of parents desperate to have their children admitted to these schools. The Government is now making it clear that those schools will be lucky if they can get funding, and there are at least 14 schools in my State whose funding has been refused.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter of great concern. It is occurring not only in Sydney. In the country, in the Dubbo area, we find that some schools have been refused funding. The proposed Lincoln Agricultural College, again a college which is being established to provide some boarding facilities for children in non-metropolitan New South Wales, has been refused recurrent funding. Anyone involved in education will know that the access available for schools with boarding facilities is limited and that for many parents in isolated areas there is a desperate need that such schools be available. Lincoln Agricultural College has applied for and sought recurrent funding. It has been refused. The Central West Christian Community School at Parkes has been refused recurrent funding, according to the list announced by the Minister last week. I and many other senators will recall, in 1982, the criticisms that Senator Ryan, then in opposition, made of some Christian community schools. It is in the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did she say?

—She attacked the philosophy which underlay their educational mission. That is okay; that is her right. On the record as a matter of history is the view Senator Ryan expressed about some of those Christian community schools. One school in the area of Parkes has been refused eligibility for recurrent funding for its years 11 and 12. That school would have had a total of 11 students in year 11 for 1986. The Central West Christian Community School began in 1982. It already had kindergarten to year 8. It has gone on expanding. Under the old guidelines, the Liberal Party guidelines, of course, the extension of funding would have been automatic. Under the Labor guidelines there will be no funding. The reason is that Senator Ryan, by back door methods, continues the war of attrition on non-government education. The facts are quite clear. I have identified the schools. If there is no war of attrition why has there been no funding?

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the fact that we understand that the Government must set its priorities in light of the available budgetary capacity which it finds it has. The Budget is often about saying no. In setting the guidelines for educational funding this Government has clearly indicated where its priorities lie. They are now priorities which are understood only too well by 14 non-government schools in my State of New South Wales which are baffled as well as angry because they do not know why they have missed out. They understand the priorities which are to limit the extension and growth of non-government education and its funding. We have heard today in explicit terms that the capital funds are to be directed towards refurbishing and not towards the creation of new places. We have seen from the Commission's comments that some of the Government's declared priorities by which it will handle its budgetary contingencies will fall most heavily upon the disadvantaged and those most needy in the community. If this is the way in which a Labor government sets its educational priorities, it is a sorry day for the Labor movement and a sorry day for education in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the opportunity, as yet, to study in any detail at all the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission which is before the Senate. I listened very attentively to the statement of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and even more attentively to the excellent reply by Senator Peter Baume which illustrated that the tabled report bears no relation at all to the bland statement of the Minister. What is happening to education under the present Hawke Government and the present Minister is quite clear. Firstly, a Schools Commission was set up and given authority as an independent body to devise policies and recommendations for the government of the day. What has happened is that that now no longer suits the government of the day. The government of the day proposes to impose its directions, its heavy hand and its policies on the whole of Commonwealth education. As a result, the Government set out to do a number of things. First, it set out to change significantly the membership of the Schools Commission, its nature and its balance of philosophy and, therefore, to get a kind of directionalism of philosophy that suited the Government. That was done, but that was not enough. So now the Schools Commission is to be emasculated. Part of it is to be taken into the Department of Education and the Department is to put its heavy hand upon the running.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the final barrier has come. It is quite clear from this report that on a number of absolutely major matters the Government has completely ignored the Schools Commission and its report. It is of no use the Government saying that its basis is underprivilege. How can it be underprivilege when, step by step, Senator Peter Baume, my colleague and a former Minister for Education who understands these matters, threw up items of underprivilege which have been ignored? The participation and equity program is to be slashed. It is a program relating to underprivilege. School after school in disadvantaged areas is to be ignored. There is a principle now which is quite different from what ought to be the concept.

It is all right for a member of the Senate as a private senator to express statements of individual and personal philosophy on education. It is quite another thing for that person, having become a Minister, to attempt to impose upon the Commonwealth of Australia personal philosophies that are not, in fact, part of the balance of the spectrum of the Australian people. It is quite wrong for a person who has expressed a view, not in equality of opportunity but in equality of outcome, to try to force such a levelling down in Australia. It is quite wrong to look at a situation in which a report comes before us which was sent for by the Minister and which says, in effect, that it would be wrong to have a major movement away from the government sector into the independent school sector because it would alter the sociological structure of Australia. What right does a government have to determine that the sociological structure shall be a particular shape or size? What right does it have to determine that, in fact, the ordinary trends of the community, decided by the judgment of individual people, should not happen? What right has a Minister to put these arbitrary barriers in the way? She has no right at all. This is, of course, social engineering at its worst. This is the socialist mind which says: `I know better than the people do; I know better than the community; I am going to force upon the community my will'.

The education system in Australia is compulsory. It is compulsory for parents to send their children to school for a range of years and syllabuses. It is not compulsory and never has been for parents to send their children to government schools. The compulsion is forced by governments which deny funding, not to rich families at all, but to the parents of ordinary middle income and poorer families so that the parents cannot make their choice and send their children to independent schools. There can be no plea from the Minister that her policies are the result of a limitation of funds. That is a nonsense statement indeed. There can be no plea from the Minister that she is cutting back only upon the affluent.

The best way for any government to save funds is to assist the movement of students from government schools to independent schools because it costs much less-50 per cent less-to maintain a child in an independent school. What are the reasons why the Government is putting these obstacles in place? They are quite clear. The obstacles are being put in place to achieve a form of social engineering, to achieve the kind of resistance to freedom of choice about which the militant unions talk freely and which the pressure of the left wing of the Labor Party tries to enforce. Everybody knows that a very significant segment of the Caucus of the Labor Party is entirely opposed to the freedom of choice. It wants to drive out freedom of choice, the right to have any independent system at all. Everybody knows the enormous pressures which are on the Minister and the Government from teacher unions and the militant, extreme leaders of the unions who are quite open in their statements that they do not want any kind of support for the independent school system.

Let us understand these things. It is no good the Minister mouthing statements that all she is doing is not helping the very rich or affluent schools. We are talking about the right of ordinary families in Harris Park, people of modest incomes, people in Labor electorates, to freedom of choice and the absolute denial of that right. It is not because there is no money; quite clearly, in the long run it must be cheaper for the Government to help and encourage that situation.

Throughout Australia when I was the Minister for Education there was a yeasting of interest at the community level to set up Christian community schools. Of course there is a desire amongst parents for freedom of choice so that there can be both spiritual and temporal atmospheres in the classroom. I would be shocked if in any way the Government were putting obstacles in the way of Christian communities getting together to establish schools--

TALK.START.PARA: —We even assist Jewish communities. We are not racist.

—The Minister cannot have it both ways. She says that she is responsible for this decision and that decision but when it is a difficult one she says it is somebody else's doing. In the long run it was the Schools Commission that made recommendations; it was the Minister who denied them. The Minister cannot have it both ways. She cannot fall back and say: `A steering committee made this decision; so I will hide behind that steering committee'. The Minister is on record as having a particular philosophy of education which is related to equality of outcome and social engineering. She is doing what is fundamentally wrong in the Westminster system. As a Minister she should be acting for the benefit of the whole of the community; she is trying to impose her own form and stamp of personal philosophy upon the community and that--
—Gross misrepresentation.

—There are tons of opportunities for the Minister to speak. Let her say that she has not changed in a particular shape or size the personnel of the Schools Commission. Let her say that she has not emasculated the Commission. Let her say that she has not done damage to the participation and equity system. Let her say that she has not refused the establishment of school after school. Once a group could come together and say: `We satisfy the temporal standards of teaching of curricula and standards of skill of teachers. We can get a certificate from the State stating that we can function as a school'. Let her deny that what was an ongoing program has been arrested. No longer does that automatically occur. Let her deny that the independent school system-both the systemic and non-systemic areas-is in great outpourings highly critical of the Government's policies. If the Opposition is wrong in what it is saying, why is the independent school system critical? It is not just the affluent at all but the whole of the systemic area that is critical. Why has a government which said to the people that it would not bring great changes to the system done so?

SPEECH.PARA: Step by step what is happening as we now see it is that the Government is putting up a pretence, a fabric, of advice. The Schools Commission is no longer there to advise or to be taken seriously; it is a pretence that there are advisers outside the Government. The real decisions are made according to the Left philosophies of the Labor Party. There are pressures upon the Government and the Minister from the teacher unions for acceptance of their philosophy. Otherwise why has the philosophy of education, which was built upon a general overview for the whole spectrum of the community, been step by step steadily moved to a form of social engineering? Why is it that we can put forward the preposterous notion of equality of outcome if ever there was one rather than the real, vibrant notion of equality of opportunity? How could we ever allow a situation that did not increase perceptibly the percentage of students in independent schools because it would alter the sociological structure of Australia? What kind of nonsense tolerates that instead of rejecting it? Why in this place has the Minister not rejected those kinds of allegations? I have not seen the report in detail. Unless any other senator wishes to speak, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I had anticipated that a full debate regarding the Government's response to the School Commission report of 1986 would take place when the legislation was introduced into this place. However, I have had to take the unusual step of seeking leave to respond to some of the matters that were raised because they were so outrageously wrong and misrepresented so grossly the facts about government policy and the facts about decisions recently taken. For the sake of those members of the public who may have been listening, I feel it is only my responsibility to correct some of the gross errors that have just been made by two sacked education spokespersons for the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A statement was made by Senator Peter Baume in relation to the new non-government schools policy-it was reiterated in an equally erroneous fashion by Senator Sir John Carrick-that there was some attempt to curtail the development of new non-government schools and that that was based on some sort of religious or race bias. I am very offended. The remarks of Senator Sir John Carrick could be interpreted only as meaning that I was acting out of some sort of prejudice against people of the Christian faith. His remarks suggested that I had some sort of Opposition to Christian education and that this philosophy was being implemented in this policy. Because such a gross insult has been perpetrated just recently in the Senate I will have to take the time of the Senate to point to the schools that were funded and, before I do that, to explain how some schools came to be funded under this category and how others did not.

As honourable senators ought to be very well aware, although some pretend to be otherwise, a new non-government schools policy was developed by the Schools Commission and accepted by the Government. The policy which is now being implemented was accepted in its entirety by the Government from the Schools Commission and that policy in turn was developed by a panel of Schools Commission commissioners, a majority of whom were representatives of the non-government sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a Government decision in the end.

—It was a Government decision in the end, as indeed it ought to be a Government decision in the end. But that Government decision happened to be a decision which accepted the recommendation of the Schools Commission. In brief, that recommendation was that the approval of new non-government schools should take place after appropriate planning procedures had been gone through. The reason was this: It is true, as both Senator Baume and Senator Sir John Carrick claim, that while they prevailed as Education Ministers there was a totally libertarian approach to the funding of new non-government schools. That is absolutely true. It is true that any school that was able to acquire registration, and in some States registration procedures were so lax as not to exist at all, could attract Commonwealth funding. The upshot of that was that many schools that received funding collapsed and the children who were enrolled by their parents in good faith were left stranded. Other schools suddenly had to accommodate those children. That was not a policy that we regarded as being in the interests of those children or any of the other children who were affected by such decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It was also the case that as a result of a totally unplanned development and proliferation of new non-government schools in areas where there was already a more than adequate supply of places, including places in the non-government sector, existing investments in government and non-government schools were seriously undermined by new schools springing up and attracting students away, at least for a period of time, and thus undermining the resources which parents had already contributed to existing non-government and government schools. As a result of these unhappy episodes, our Government decided, in consultation with the Schools Commission and all of the interests with which the Schools Commission constantly consults, to have a much more thorough planned approach to the development of new non-government schools. Under that planned approach, no school which has adequately consulted and has planned in co-operation with State and non-government school authorities will not be funded.

The list of schools to which both Senator Baume and Senator Sir John Carrick referred in the most unbalanced and misleading fashion was actually a list of schools brought before me as Minister by the Schools Commission after decisions had been made at State level by State planning committees on which non-government school representatives have, I think, majority representation; certainly in some States they do. Each of those State committees assessed applications. They then afforded a priority category to those representations. They had high and medium priorities, both of which were consistent with planned educational provision. They then had low and lowest, which were proposals that were not consistent with planned educational provision. This meant, in lay persons' talk, that those schools would be taking students away from schools which were already adequately supplied with places. Those judgments were by and large accepted by our Government and by me as Minister. There were two cases of schools which were not given a high priority funding and to which, after I sought further information, I decided to give funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which were they?

—I will not answer that interjection. So, as a result of this process and to be consistent with the planned educational provision policy endorsed by the Schools Commission, all of the schools that were recommended by the State committees were in fact funded. For the benefit of honourable senators and in face of the implied religious or race bias that I was subjected to recently let me read out a range of schools-I will not read out all 68 of them. Honest people listening to this debate can then make their own assessment about whether our Government is in any way hostile to Christian education, as was implied by Senator Sir John Carrick. In New South Wales, the State from which both honourable senators come, new schools approved for funding include the Broughton Anglican College; Catherine McAuley Girls School, Westmead; Domremy College, Five Dock; Dubbo Christian School-which was commented on by Senator Baume; Eaglevale Catholic Primary; Eukarima School; Gateway Christian School; Heritage Christian School; Illawarra Christian School; John Paul College; Masada College; Menai Catholic Primary; Mount Carmel High School, Varroville; Mullumbimby Community School; Newcastle Christian Life Academy; Our Lady of the Rosary, Waitara; Redfield College, Cherrybrook; Southern Highlands Christian School, Bowral; Special School for Autistic Children, Cringila; St Mary's Primary School, East Orange; St Mary's Rosebank College, Five Dock; St Michael's Primary School, Booragul; Sutherland Shire Christian School; Taree Catholic High School; and Windsor Catholic Secondary School, South Windsor. That is only one State. I could go on State by State.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable senators were counting they would have noted a preponderance of schools established precisely on the Christian philosophy and calling themselves Christian schools that have been funded, as have Jewish schools and Christian orthodox schools. A further list contains the Oakleigh Greek Orthodox College and an Islamic primary and secondary school. So the list goes on. The list also contains the Clontarf Aboriginal School, Seventh Day Adventist schools and so on. Both honourable senators have seen this list. Both know that the 68 schools that I announced as being approved for funding included a preponderance, I would say, of Christian schools and a very broad diversity of schools based on other religious philosophies as well as some schools which are based on philosophies which are not connected with any particular religion.

How any honest senator, reading that list, could get up in this place and accuse me and, by implication, our Government of having some sort of hostility to Christian schools is a matter of great concern and almost incomprehension by me. Both of the honourable senators who made these disgraceful imputations have been Education Ministers. They know that the Commonwealth does not involve itself in concern about the religious or other philosophy of a school. They know that the matter of the registration of schools is a matter of State responsibility with which we do not seek to interfere. It is at that point the curriculum of the school, including what will be offered in terms of religious or any other philosophical instruction, is assessed. That is not a matter in which the Commonwealth Schools Commission or the Commonwealth Government involves itself in any way.

What the Commonwealth has to do is to make sure that scarce resources are spread fairly throughout the community and I believe that the list that I have just read out gives some indication of the diversity of schools which are being funded under our policy. At the same time, we have to ensure that schools which we fund are economically viable, that they are not going to collapse a few months after children are enrolled and that they are not being developed in areas where other non-government schools or government schools will be seriously--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or government schools?

—Or government schools will be seriously affected by their development. These are reasonable planning procedures which do not in any way involve any judgments about the religious philosophy of the community organising the school. I think it is very unfortunate that such accusations have been made. The only thing I can say is that, as the schools community is an increasingly well informed community, it will have no truck with suggestions of this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to other points made by Senator Baume in regard to the Schools Commission report, of course not every recommendation for funding was accepted. Of course in a budgetary situation like ours, we do not achieve the ideal in terms of funding. Of course we would like to be able to spend more money in special education and in the disadvantaged schools program and many others. The Commission rightly makes recommendations for funding. We assess those. We are not able to meet all of those recommendations. Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Baume would know that when they were Ministers for Education the Fraser Government similarly did not fund to the level of every recommendation of the Schools Commission. In fact, the last time I made an assessment of the success of the Schools Commission recommendations under the Fraser Government compared with the recommendations under the Hawke Government I think we were ahead on accepting recommendations. Be that as it may, Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Baume will know that when they were Ministers for Education no report of the Schools Commission had every recommendation for funding met fully by the government of the day because governments have budgetary constraints upon them and they also make judgments. It is true, as both honourable senators suggested, that in the end these decisions are government decisions, and properly so, but they are decisions taken in the light of public advice given by the Schools Commission-advice which is derived from extensive consultations with all interested parties; advice which is made available in this place for debate. The public can judge the Government's performance in relation to that advice. That situation will continue to prevail because the Schools Commission will continue to do what it has done today-bring reports to the Government, have those reports tabled and have Government responses tabled so that senators and anyone else interested can make up their minds about what the Government has decided to do in relation to recommendations. That is a proper procedure and one with which we will certainly continue. Any suggestion that there is something improper or outside the Westminster system in our not funding every single recommendation of the Schools Commission is absolutely absurd.

I do not propose to keep the Senate at this stage because, as I have said, the matters that I outlined in my ministerial statement will require that legislation be passed through this place and there will then be ample opportunity for further debate. I simply conclude by saying that I cannot understand why senators who claim to be concerned about education and educational opportunities find it useful to misrepresent what has actually happened. I understand that senators with a different philosophy may be critical of decisions we make but I cannot understand why they choose not simply to criticise the decisions we have made but to misrepresent wildly those decisions. Let us agree on the facts and then let us have a debate on them. I express the hope that erroneous interpretations and untruthful claims and assertions can be left aside. We are quite prepared to defend the decisions we have made and the reasons for which we made them.

DEBATE.TITLE: MOUNT ALLAN LAND CLAIMGURINDJI LAND CLAIM TO DAGURAGU STATION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Further Report by Aboriginal Land Commissioner

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The reports on the Mount Allan and Gurindji land claims concern claims made in the Northern Territory by the land councils in those areas. I want to make two short points. First, in looking at the claims made by Aboriginals in the Northern Territory it has to be remembered that, bearing in mind the area of land involved, their claims are moderate, given the history of the Northern Territory and given the history of the Aboriginals in that area, which goes back well before the time of white settlement in Australia. It is often suggested these days that the claims and amounts granted on the basis of those claims are excessive. It is well to remember in reading these reports that that is not so.

The second thing I want to talk about is the representation made on behalf of the Aboriginals in respect of both these claims. I know that in the Mount Allan land claim Mr John Coldrey and Mr Hird appeared for the claimants, and Mr Ross Howie appeared in relation to the other claim. Mr Howie and Mr Coldrey come from the Victorian Bar, and they went to the Northern Territory to appear on behalf of the Aboriginals in that area. They gave up successful and lucrative practices over that time. Credit ought to be given to them, and I do so in this address.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Cooney in commenting upon the Mount Allan and Gurindji land claims. There is an unfortunate spirit abroad in the community at present which would assert that land is being handed to Aboriginal communities in some capricious, careless or reckless way under provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The tabling of the reports on these two claims is one more occasion on which we can set that record straight. These reports by two Aboriginal land commissioners, Sir William Kearney and Mr Justice Maurice, are merely steps along the way by which land claims are processed; they are not in themselves the granting of land to anyone. Those of us who have been Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs will know that built into the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 are quite severe requirements which need to be met before Aboriginal communities can claim land. Procedures are laid down which must be followed before a recommendation can go to the Government that land should be granted. Even at that stage the Act provides that the Minister must exercise further judgment and must make a decision before any land trust is established.

SPEECH.PARA: I put on record once again that in my time as Minister there were at least a couple of occasions when I declined for good and proper reasons to establish a land trust even where one had been recommended. One occasion involved the land at Vanderlin Island, associated with the Borroloola claim, where to have granted the land trust would have meant dispossessing another Aboriginal person who had some claim to the land but who, under the terms of the Act as it was drafted, would have had no right. No one really objected to that ministerial decision; the Aboriginal community understood it. The other claim which caused a lot of concern-I do not even know whether it is resolved now-was the claim in relation to Beetaloo Station where some Aboriginal people held a pastoral lease but under the Act as it is drafted it was possible for those who alleged that they were traditional owners to claim the land and have their land claim heard.

In the few minutes available to me I wish to confine my comments on the annual report of the Department of the Treasury to what I see as the need for better economic growth statistics in Australia. I am concerned about the increasingly misleading nature of certain of our key measurements of economic growth. I refer particularly to gross national expenditure, or GNE, as a measure of economic growth. In recent years an increasing part of GNE has been on deficit financed public administration and community services. This has had the effect of bloating the figures for the growth of GNE that the Government provides. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), for example, uses GNE figures as support for his fatuous claims that he has somehow defeated the business cycle. Gross national expenditure should no longer be taken to reflect the growth of the true growth potential, or the rise in national productivity and living standards.

I would like to see the Treasury and the Australian Bureau of Statistics consider the preparation and publication of a measure of what I would call private domestic product which, in my view, would better reflect the genuine productive potential of the national economy. The definition of this concept, PDP, would be total gross domestic product in real terms, minus public administration, defence, community services, ownership of dwellings and customs duty adjustment. These items reflect wealth-using expenditures and not wealth-creating, productive, activities. The growth trend of PDP and PDP per capita has had a pronounced downward kink since about 1973.

On a per capita basis, private domestic product-that is, in effect our private productive potential-grew by only 0.8 per cent per annum over the decade to 1982-83, compared with 3.1 per cent per annum in the decade 1962-63 to 1972-73. More recent figures than those for 1982-83 are not yet available. This sad fact appears to indicate that the Australian statistics system reflects the public interest in spending and a lack of interest in production. Whilst the bloated gross national expenditure figures are published with a time lag of only about four months, statistics for gross domestic product by industry are published after a lag of one or two years.

I am indebted to Professor Wolfgang Kasper of the Royal Military College, Duntroon, for suggestions which formed the basis of my brief remarks today. I hope that professional economists and the relevant government authorities, including the Treasury, will give these suggestions careful consideration in the interest of providing a more accurate statistical guide to economic growth and productive potential in Australia.
